text:
Hi! I would like to fix the following in Julia 1.6:
```using Dates
t0 = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 9)
tend = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 12)
(t0:tend) .+ Day(1)```
Too late?

elements.text: Hi! I would like to fix the following in Julia 1.6:

using Dates
t0 = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 9)
tend = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 12)
(t0:tend) .+ Day(1)
Too late?

text: so the problem seems to be `t0:tend` which errors for dates and times

elements.text: so the problem seems to be
t0:tend
which errors for dates and times

text: You just have to specify the step

elements.text: You just have to specify the step

text: yes but I want the users to express `t0:tend` as an interval

elements.text: yes but I want the users to express
t0:tend
as an interval

text: but that's probably not the intended use here

elements.text: but that's probably not the intended use here
I can probably use IntervalSets

text: To expand on what <@U67SCG4HG> said, I think there isn’t a default step for a `DateTime` range, so you need to specify one explicitly (e.g. `t0:Day(1):tend`). If you just want the end points, then maybe an `NTuple{DateTime,2}` would be better suited.

elements.text: To expand on what
said, I think there isn’t a default step for a
DateTime
range, so you need to specify one explicitly (e.g.
t0:Day(1):tend
). If you just want the end points, then maybe an
NTuple{DateTime,2}
would be better suited.

text: Sorry, didn’t see the 1.6 part of your question, so please take my response modulo 1.5 :sweat_smile:
